Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They offer small gestures of kindness in daily interactions
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code for the core module half-finished. The project manager’s email was curt: “We can’t move forward until your part is done.” I knew the whole team was waiting on me, their progress stalled. As an engineer, I felt the weight of responsibility pressing down—my work was the linchpin, and I was expected to deliver a flawless solution, fast.

But then, as I was about to dive back in, I noticed my colleague Sarah at the next desk, her eyes red and shoulders slumped. She’d been quiet all morning. My heart tugged at me—my faith taught me to show kindness, to reach out, to be present for others in their struggles. I wanted to offer a listening ear, maybe a comforting word or a cup of coffee. Yet, every minute I spent away from my code would delay the project even more, letting my team down.

I sat frozen, torn between the urgent demands of my role as an engineer and the quiet call of compassion that my faith instilled in me.
